sen.j: 大森彦七盛長（おおもりひこしちもりなが）は、清和源氏に属する南北朝時代 (日本)の武将。
sen.e: Morinaga Hikoshichi OMORI was a busho (Japanese military commander) of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).
Morinaga Hikoshichi OMORI was a busho (Japanese military commander) of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).
Morinaga Hikoshichi OMORI was a busho (Japanese military commander) of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

sen.j: 伊予国砥部庄千里城の城主。
sen.e: He was the lord of Tobesho Seri-jo Castle in Iyo Province.
He was the lord of Tobesho Seri-jo Castle in Iyo Province.
He was the lord of Tobesho Seri-jo Castle in Iyo Province.

sen.j: 大和源氏祖である源頼親の9代孫。
sen.e: He was the ninth generation of the descendent of MINAMOTO no Yorichika, who was the ancestor of Yamato-Genji (Minamoto clan).
He was the ninth generation as a descendent of MINAMOTO no Yorichika, who was the ancestor of Yamato-Genji (Minamoto clan).
He was the ninth generation as a descendent of MINAMOTO no Yorichika, who was the ancestor of Yamato-Genji (Minamoto clan).

sen.j: 源親治(宇野親治)の5代孫。
sen.e: He was the fifth generation of the descendent of MINAMOTO no Chikaharu (Chikaharu UNO).
He was the fifth generation as a descendent of MINAMOTO no Chikaharu (Chikaharu UNO).
He was the fifth generation as a descendent of MINAMOTO no Chikaharu (Chikaharu UNO).

sen.j: 現愛媛県砥部町の住人にして、太平記に怪異話の主人公として載せられている。
sen.e: He lived in the present-day Tobe town in Ehime Prefecture and was a central character in a grotesque story according to "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace).
He lived in present-day Tobe town in Ehime Prefecture and was described as a central character in a grotesque story of "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace).
He lived in present-day Tobe town in Ehime Prefecture and was described as a central character in a grotesque story of "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace).

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 建武 (日本)3年（1336年）の湊川の戦いにおいて、宮方の名将楠木正成を敗死させたという伝説が残っているが定かではない。
sen.e: There is a legend that, in 1336 in the Battle of Minato-gawa River, he killed Masashige KUSUNOKI, a great commander on the court's side, but this is uncertain.
There is a legend that, in 1336 in the Battle of Minato-gawa River, he killed Masashige KUSUNOKI, a great commander on the court's side, but this is uncertain.
There is a legend that, in 1336 in the Battle of Minato-gawa River, he killed Masashige KUSUNOKI, a great commander on the court's side, but this is uncertain.

sen.j: この戦いの褒賞として讃岐国（現香川県）を与えられる。
sen.e: As an incentive award for the battle, he was given Sanuki Province (the present-day Kagawa Prefecture).
As an incentive award for the battle, he was given Sanuki Province (present-day Kagawa Prefecture).
As an incentive award for the battle, he was given Sanuki Province (present-day Kagawa Prefecture).

sen.j: この一派を伊豫大森氏といい、備前国、伊予国、因幡国、出雲国で繁栄している。
sen.e: His group was called Iyo Omori clan and was prosperous in Bizen Province, Iyo Province, Inaba Province, and Izumo Province.
His group was called Iyo Omori clan and was prosperous in Bizen Province, Iyo Province, Inaba Province, and Izumo Province.
His group was called Iyo Omori clan and was prosperous in Bizen Province, Iyo Province, Inaba Province, and Izumo Province.

sen.j: 暦応3年（1340年）、宮方の脇屋義助（新田義貞の弟）の四国制圧により形勢逆転したが、武家側細川頼春来襲により形勢が再逆転した。
sen.e: In 1340, the situation reversed by the control of Shikoku by Yoshisuke WAKIYA (Yoshisada NITTA's younger brother) on the court's side, but the situation reversed again by the invasion of Yoriharu HOSOKAWA on the samurai side.

In 1340, the situation reversed due to the control of Shikoku by Yoshisuke WAKIYA (Yoshisada NITTA's younger brother) of the court's side, but the situation reversed again due to the invasion by Yoriharu HOSOKAWA of the samurai side.
sen.cmt: 表現（前置詞など）の見直し
sen.e: In 1340, the situation reversed due to the control of Shikoku by Yoshisuke WAKIYA (Yoshisada NITTA's younger brother) of the court's side, but the situation reversed again due to the invasion by Yoriharu HOSOKAWA of the samurai side.

sen.j: これにより砥部中山遊猟地2000貫を加賜された。
sen.e: As a result, he was awarded the additional 2000 kan (a unit for the fields, which was determined on the basis of the yields and did not depend on the areas) of hunting fields in Tobe Nakayama.
As a result, he was awarded the additional 2000 kan (a unit for the fields, which was determined on the basis of the yields and did not depend on the areas) of hunting fields in Tobe Nakayama.
As a result, he was awarded the additional 2000 kan (a unit for the fields, which was determined on the basis of the yields and did not depend on the areas) of hunting fields in Tobe Nakayama.

sen.j: 神前郷松前村（現在の愛媛県伊予郡松前町 (愛媛県)）金蓮寺へ向かう途中、重光の部落を流れる矢取川で楠木正成の怨霊の化身「鬼女」に出くわしたという伝説がある（『太平記』）。
sen.e: There is a legend that, on the way to Konren-ji Temple in Masaki-mura in Kamusakigo (present-day Masaki Cho, Iyo County, Ehime Prefecture), he encountered "Kijo" (an ogress), an incarnation of a vengeful spirit of Masashige KUSUNOKI, at Yatori-gawa River that ran through the hamlet of Shigemitsu ("Taiheiki").

There is a legend that, on the way to Konren-ji Temple in Masaki-mura in Kamusakigo (present-day Masaki Cho, Iyo County, Ehime Prefecture), he encountered "Kijo" (an ogress), an incarnation of a vengeful spirit of Masashige KUSUNOKI, at Yatori-gawa River that ran through the hamlet of Shigemitsu ("Taiheiki").

There is a legend that, on the way to Konren-ji Temple in Masaki-mura in Kamusakigo (present-day Masaki Cho, Iyo County, Ehime Prefecture), he encountered "Kijo" (an ogress), an incarnation of a vengeful spirit of Masashige KUSUNOKI, at Yatori-gawa River that ran through the hamlet of Shigemitsu ("Taiheiki").

sen.j: この物語は江戸時代には舞踊劇となり、明治時代には福地桜痴の史劇「大森彦七」が新歌舞伎の18番の1つとして上演された。
sen.e: This story was made into a dance drama in the Edo period, and a historical drama called "Omori Hikoshichi" created by Ochi FUKUCHI was performed in the Meiji period as a specialty of new kabuki.
This story was made into a dance drama in the Edo period, and a historical drama called "Omori Hikoshichi" created by Ochi FUKUCHI was performed in the Meiji period as a specialty of new kabuki.

sen.j: この大森盛長の子孫大森盛頼が伊予国風早郡小川村に入ってくる。
sen.e: Moriyori OMORI, the descendant of Morinaga OMORI, entered Ogawa-mura, Kazahaya District, Iyo Province.
Moriyori OMORI, the descendant of Morinaga OMORI, entered Ogawa-mura, Kazahaya District, Iyo Province.
Moriyori OMORI, the descendant of Morinaga OMORI, entered Ogawa-mura, Kazahaya District, Iyo Province.

sen.j: その孫大森盛安が文禄元年（1592年）に小川村の庄屋として任命される。
sen.e: His grandson Moriyasu OMORI was appointed as shoya (village headman) in Ogawa-mura in 1592.
His grandson Moriyasu OMORI was appointed as shoya (village headman) in Ogawa-mura in 1592.
His grandson Moriyasu OMORI was appointed as shoya (village headman) in Ogawa-mura in 1592.

sen.j: それから10代300年の間、明治時代に庄屋制が廃止されるまで小川村の庄屋大森家はとぎれることなく続いたのである」(木村中著『伊予の奇傑大森彦七』)
sen.e: Over 300 years and ten generations thereafter, until the shoya system was discontinued in the Meiji period, the shoya Omori family in Ogawa-mura continued without interruption ("Hikoshichi OMORI- a remarkable person in Iyo" by Naka KIMURA).

Over 300 years and ten generations thereafter, until the shoya system was discontinued in the Meiji period, the shoya Omori family in Ogawa-mura had continued without interruption ("Hikoshichi OMORI- a remarkable person in Iyo" by Naka KIMURA).

Over 300 years and ten generations thereafter, until the shoya system was discontinued in the Meiji period, the shoya Omori family in Ogawa-mura had continued without interruption ("Hikoshichi OMORI- a remarkable person in Iyo" by Naka KIMURA).

sen.j: その大森家が廃屋となり、残されていた襖の下張りから藩政時代から明治初期にかけての古文書が発見された。
sen.e: After the Omori family was abandoned, ancient documents from the period of domain duties to the early Meiji period were found in the underlining of the remaining Fusuma (Japanese sliding door).
After the Omori family was abandoned, ancient documents from the period of domain duties to the early Meiji period were found in the underlining of the remaining Fusuma (Japanese sliding door).
After the Omori family was abandoned, ancient documents from the period of domain duties to the early Meiji period were found in the underlining of the remaining Fusuma (Japanese sliding door).

sen.j: 大森家の屏風に霧を吹き一枚々剥がし乾燥させ読み取る作業の中から、佐賀の乱の江藤新平手配書が屏風の下張りの中から見つかった。
sen.e: By the process of spraying folding screens of the Omori family with water, taking the screen off one by one, drying and reading it, a wanted poster of Shinpei ETO in the Saga War was found in the underlining of the folding screen.

By the process of spraying folding screens of the Omori family with water, taking off sheets on the screens one by one, and drying them to read, a wanted poster of Shinpei ETO during the Saga War was found in the underlining of the folding screen.

By the process of spraying folding screens of the Omori family with water, taking off sheets on the screens one by one, and drying them to read, a wanted poster of Shinpei ETO during the Saga War was found in the underlining of the folding screen.

sen.j: この二本が基本となって、様々な怪異話が派生してくるのではある。
sen.e: On the basis of these two stories, various grotesque stories have derived.

sen.j: 入手も容易であるので、詳細は省き、以下では容易に手に入れがたい地方説話の中の大森彦七を取り上げておくことにする。
sen.e: Since these books are readily available, details are omitted herein and the story of Hikoshichi OMORI, which is not readily available of local stories, will be described.

sen.j: 予州大洲領御替地古今集
sen.e: Yoshu Ozu ryo okaechi kokinshu
Yoshu Ozu ryo okaechi kokinshu

sen.j: むかし塩売り昼寝してありしが、この渕より大蛇出て塩売りを呑まんとしてねらひ寄る。
sen.e: Once upon a time, when a salt man was taking a nap, a dragon appeared from the deep water, trying to swallow the man.
Once upon a time, when a salt salesman was taking a nap, a dragon appeared from the deep water, trying to swallow the man.
Once upon a time, when a salt salesman was taking a nap, a dragon appeared from the deep water, trying to swallow the man.

sen.j: 籠の内に塩の価に取りたる剣あり、自ら抜け出て彼の蛇を追ふ。
sen.e: There was a basket containing a sword having the same value as the salt, and the sword came right out of basket by itself and chased his dragon.
There was a basket containing a sword having the same value as the salt, and the sword came right out of basket by itself and chased his dragon.
There was a basket containing a sword having the same value as the salt, and the sword came right out of basket by itself and chased his dragon.

sen.j: 大森彦七通りかかり、その霊剣たることを知り、家来に商人を起こさせ右剣を所望し、持刀となす。
sen.e: Hikoshichi OMORI happened to passed by the man and came to know that the sword had a soul, and he ordered his retainer to obtain the sword, ended up possessing the sword.
Hikoshichi OMORI happened to passed by the man and came to know that the sword had a soul, and he ordered his retainer to obtain the sword, ended up possessing the sword.
Hikoshichi OMORI happened to passed by the man and came to know that the sword had a soul, and he ordered his retainer to obtain the sword, ended up possessing the sword.

sen.j: 故に塩売渕と言ひ伝ふ。
sen.e: Accordingly, people call shiourifuchi (a salt man from the deep water.
Accordingly, people call the place shiourifuchi (salt sales deep water).

sen.j: 同上
sen.e: Ditto
Ditto
Ditto

sen.j: 矢取り川の岸に大森彦七が通りかかると、美麗なる女、地蔵堂の辺より出て川を渡し給れと云ふにつき、背に負ひ川中に至ると大磐石を負たる如く、下見れば鬼の形水にうつる。
sen.e: When Hikoshichi OMORI happened to pass by the bank of Yatori-gawa River, a beautiful woman came out of the Jizo-do Hall and told him to make her pass the river; so he carried her on his back and as he reached the middle of the river, he felt like he was carrying a huge rock; the surface of the water reflected an ogre.

When Hikoshichi OMORI happened to pass by the bank of Yatori-gawa River, a beautiful woman came out of the Jizo-do Hall and told him to make her pass the river; so he carried her on his back and as he reached the middle of the river, he felt like he was carrying a huge rock; the surface of the water reflected an ogre.

When Hikoshichi OMORI happened to pass by the bank of Yatori-gawa River, a beautiful woman came out of the Jizo-do Hall and told him to make her pass the river; so he carried her on his back and as he reached the middle of the river, he felt like he was carrying a huge rock; the surface of the water reflected an ogre.

sen.j: 即時に彦七をつかみ虚空にのぼる。
sen.e: Suddenly, the ogre grabbed Hikoshichi and rose up to the sky.
Suddenly, the ogre grabbed Hikoshichi and rose up to the sky.
Suddenly, the ogre grabbed Hikoshichi and rose up to the sky.

sen.j: 家来驚き見送れば俤逆に見えしとて坂面山と言ふ、鬼形水にうつりしを名づけて鏡川という。
sen.e: While the surprised retainer kept watching the situation, Hikoshichi said that a mountain appeared upside down, thereby calling it Mt. Sakazura, and as the water reflected the shape of the ogre, the river was called Kagami-gawa River.

While the surprised retainer kept watching the situation, Hikoshichi said that a mountain appeared upside down, thereby calling it Mt. Sakazura, and as the water reflected the shape of the ogre, the river was called Kagami-gawa River.

While the surprised retainer kept watching the situation, Hikoshichi said that a mountain appeared upside down, thereby calling it Mt. Sakazura, and as the water reflected the shape of the ogre, the river was called Kagami-gawa River.

Ozu Kyuki (The old record of Ozu), Shimoaso Village
Ozu Kyuki (The old record of Ozu), Shimoaso Village

sen.j: 昔仏来光しとて来迎山と云有。
sen.e: Once upon a time, the Buddha appeared with light at a mountain, thereby the mountain was called Mt. Raigo.
Once upon a time, Buddha appeared with light on a mountain, thereby the mountain was called Mt. Raigo-yama.
Once upon a time, Buddha appeared with light on a mountain, thereby the mountain was called Mt. Raigo-yama.

sen.j: 又釈迦面山と云有。
sen.e: Another mountain was called Mt. Shakatsura.
The mountain was also called Mt. Shakatsura-yama.
The mountain was also called Mt. Shakatsura-yama.

sen.j: 是を逆面山と云。
sen.e: This was then called Mt. Sakatsura.
It was eventually called Mt. Sakatsura-yama.
It was eventually called Mt. Sakatsura-yama.

sen.j: 大森彦七化生の物につかまれ、虚空に引き上げられ、逆様に落るを見て、さかつら山と云と雖、来迎山有ば釈迦つら山を誤りたる成るべし。
sen.e: Hikoshichi OMORI was grabbed by a specter and was held up into the sky, seeing the view upside down, calling the mountain Mt. Sakatsura; however, as there already existed Mt. Raigo, this mountain was erroneously called Mt. Shakatsura.

Hikoshichi OMORI was grabbed by a specter and was held up into the sky, seeing the view upside down, calling the mountain Mt. Sakatsura-yama; however, as there already existed Mt. Raigo-yama, this mountain was erroneously called Mt. Shakatsura-yama.
sen.cmt: 山の名前の最後に-yamaを付与。
sen.e: Hikoshichi OMORI was grabbed by a specter and was held up into the sky, seeing the view upside down, calling the mountain Mt. Sakatsura-yama; however, as there already existed Mt. Raigo-yama, this mountain was erroneously called Mt. Shakatsura-yama.

sen.j: 魔住みの窪と云有。
sen.e: There was a hollow place where a demon lived.

sen.j: 大森彦七屋敷にて、化生の物出しより号たりと、左に記事、此所の由、已前より其名高し、俗誤りて茄が窪と云非也。
sen.e: At Hikoshichi OMORI's residence, a specter appeared and

sen.j: 鏡川と云は、矢取川の事也。

sen.j: 美女鬼になりしを水にうつる故、見附たりと也。
sen.e: A beautiful woman became an ogre reflected on the water and thus was found.

sen.j: 彦七大庄を二三ケ所給ふと云、砥部庄松前辺也。
sen.e: Hikoshichi was given a few territories in Daisho, which were called Tobesho Matsumae.

sen.j: 舞台は松前金蓮寺也と云。

sen.j: 石上山光明寺、此寺般若経大森が怪異の時真読せし般若経巻なるよし。

sen.j: 彦七塩売りより求めたる太刀弥其功有て化生の物をつき留などしたる後、此宮に納、左の殿に祭ると宝剣殿と云。
sen.e: The sword which Hikoshichi asked the salt man to give in was enshrined in this shrine after effectively killing the specter; the left hall which enshrined the sword was called hokenden.

sen.j: 応永年中千里の城に三足の化生出、神主倉持太夫於神前鳴弦執行、化生退散すと云。
sen.e: In the Oei era, a specter with three legs appeared in Seri-jo Castle; a Shinto priest Kuramochi dayu played a string in front of the god, thereby clearing out the specter.

There used to grow Toranoozakura (cherry blossoms).
There used to grow Toranoozakura (cherry blossoms).

sen.j: 四十年程後に枯れたりと、已前の怪異を様々語る。
sen.e: The tree died down forty years later, telling the old various grotesque stories.
The tree died down forty years later, while people telling various old grotesque stories.
The tree died down forty years later, while people telling various old grotesque stories.

sen.j: 同上 大平村
sen.e: Ditto Ohira Village
Ditto Ohira Village
Ditto Ohira Village

sen.j: 峯と云山に夜毎に火もゆる。
sen.e: A mountain called Mine saw a fire every night.
A mountain called Mine showed a fire every night.
A mountain called Mine showed a fire every night.

sen.j: 世に云金の炎也。
sen.e: It was publicly called the fire of gold.
It was publicly called the fire of gold.
It was publicly called the fire of gold.

sen.j: 千里城落たる時、金の茶臼埋めたりと云。
sen.e: When Seri-jo Castle fell, a gold chausu (tea grinding mortar) was buried.
When Seri-jo Castle fell, a gold chausu (tea grinding mortar) was buried.
When Seri-jo Castle fell, a gold chausu (tea grinding mortar) was buried.

sen.j: 予陽盛衰記
sen.e: Yoyo Seisuiki (Rise and Fall of Yoyo)
Yoyo Seisuiki (Rise and Fall of Yoyo)
Yoyo Seisuiki (Rise and Fall of Yoyo)

sen.j: 大森彦七盛長久米郡の住人。
sen.e: Hikoshichi Morinaga OMORI lived in Kume County.
Hikoshichi Morinaga OMORI lived in Kume County.
Hikoshichi Morinaga OMORI lived in Kume County.

sen.j: この盛長と云う者土佐の奥に有りて日夜山林を家とし鹿猿兎を猟て業とし飽くまで剛強にして不敵なり。
sen.e: A person named Morinaga survived deep in Tosa and spent every night in mountains; he hunt deers, monkeys, and rabbits to make a living, being strong and fearless forever.
A person named Morinaga survived deep in Tosa and spent every night in mountains; he hunted deers, monkeys, and rabbits to make a living, being strong and fearless forever.
A person named Morinaga survived deep in Tosa and spent every night in mountains; he hunted deers, monkeys, and rabbits to make a living, being strong and fearless forever.

sen.j: 伊予温故録 金蓮寺
sen.e: Iyo Onkoroku Konren-ji Temple
Iyo Onkoroku Konren-ji Temple
Iyo Onkoroku Konren-ji Temple

sen.j: 堂前に大石あり、大森彦七盛長が印しの石なり
sen.e: There was a huge stone in front of the hall, which stone was signed by Hikoshichi Morinaga OMORI.
There was a huge stone in front of the hall, and the stone had a sign of Hikoshichi Morinaga OMORI.
There was a huge stone in front of the hall, and the stone had a sign of Hikoshichi Morinaga OMORI.

sen.j: 同上 谷上山宝珠寺
sen.e: Ditto Mt. Tagami Hosho-ji Temple
Ditto Tagamiyama Hosho-ji Temple
sen.cmt: Mt. Tagami Hosho-ji Temple-->Tagamiyama Hosho-ji Temple
sen.e: Ditto Tagamiyama Hosho-ji Temple

sen.j: 文政年中火災に罹り悉く消失す。
sen.e: The temple was destroyed by fire in the Bunsei era.
The temple was destroyed by fire in the Bunsei era.
The temple was destroyed by fire in the Bunsei era.

sen.j: 其の中大森彦七納むる所の甲冑一領を存す。
sen.e: Under the circumstances, a set of Kacchu (armor and helmet) placed by Hikoshichi OMORI survived the fire.
Under the circumstances, a set of Kacchu (armor and helmet) placed by Hikoshichi OMORI survived the fire.
Under the circumstances, a set of Kacchu (armor and helmet) placed by Hikoshichi OMORI survived the fire.

sen.j: 同上 千里城、城主神社
sen.e: Ditto Seri-jo Castle, Shironushi Shrine
Ditto Seri-jo Castle, Shironushi Shrine
Ditto Seri-jo Castle, Shironushi Shrine

sen.j: 千里城、川登村字千里にあり、大森彦七盛長居る。
sen.e: Seri-jo Castle was located in Senri, Kawanobori Village, where Hikoshichi Morinaga OMORI lived.
Seri-jo Castle was located in Senri, Kawanobori Village, where Hikoshichi Morinaga OMORI lived.
Seri-jo Castle was located in Senri, Kawanobori Village, where Hikoshichi Morinaga OMORI lived.

sen.j: 後ち平岡民部之丞居る。
sen.e: Later, Hiraoka Minbu no jo (the third officer of tax and urban improvement department) lived.
Later, Hiraoka Minbu no jo (the third officer of tax and urban improvement department) lived.
Later, Hiraoka Minbu no jo (the third officer of tax and urban improvement department) lived.

sen.j: 城山の南下に盛長の建てたる茶屋あり。
sen.e: In the south of the castle, there was a chaya (tea house) built by Morinaga.
In the south of the castle, there was a chaya (tea house) built by Morinaga.
In the south of the castle, there was a chaya (tea house) built by Morinaga.

sen.j: 城主神社、川登村字千里に有り、大森彦七以下類族の霊を祭る。
sen.e: Shironushi Shrine was located in Senri, Kawanobori Village, where Hikoshichi OMORI and seven other relatives were enshrined.
Shironushi Shrine was located in Senri, Kawanobori Village, where Hikoshichi OMORI and his relatives were enshrined.
Shironushi Shrine was located in Senri, Kawanobori Village, where Hikoshichi OMORI and his relatives were enshrined.

sen.j: 大森の子孫代々千里城主たりしが、荏原の平岡氏に攻められ、文明十一年十二月二十九日落城の時此神社を創建すと云ふ。
sen.e: Omori's descendants became the lord of Seri-jo Castle generation by generation; however they were defeated by the Hiraoka clan in Ebara, and built the shrine on February 18, 1480 when the castle fell.

Omori's descendants had become the lord of Seri-jo Castle generation by generation; however they were defeated by the Hiraoka clan in Ebara, and built the shrine on February 18, 1480 when the castle fell.

Omori's descendants had become the lord of Seri-jo Castle generation by generation; however they were defeated by the Hiraoka clan in Ebara, and built the shrine on February 18, 1480 when the castle fell.

sen.j: 伊予古蹟志
sen.e: Iyo Kosekishi
Iyo Kosekishi
Iyo Kosekishi

sen.j: 五本松有館墟、日彦七宮、古大森盛長家居之遺構也。
sen.e: A residence with five pine trees became abandoned, and Nichihiko Shichinomiya Shrine and the old residence of Morinaga OMORI remained.
A residence with five pine trees became abandoned, and Nichihiko Shichinomiya Shrine and the old residence of Morinaga OMORI remained.
